note.p: Education: Studied humanities with the Jesuits and mathematics with Settimi

Career: Assistant to Galileo Galilei at Arcetri (1639); wrote an account of Galileo's life; prevented from continuing his work by the opposition of the Roman Catholic Church, he turned his attention to reconstructing and translating the mathematical texts of the ancients, including Euclid's 'Elements'; declined the offer of scientific posts from King John II Casimir of Poland and Louis XIV of France
Memberships: Accademia del Cimento, Florence; Academie Royale des Sciences (1699, Foreign Member )
References: E N da C Andrade, 'Galileo' in NR 1964 vol 19 pp 120-130
Marco Beretta, 'At the source of Western science: the organization of experimentalism at the Accadmeia del Cimento (1657-1667)' in NR 2000 vol 54 pp 131-151
A Cook, '1703 and other anniversaries' in NR 2003 vol 57 pp 1-2
A Cook, 'Rome and the Royal Society, 1660-1740' in NR 2004 vol 58 pp 3-19
